details></android.view.View__></android.widget.ListView__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Description></android.view.View__Description><android.view.View__Product Description></android.view.View__Product Description><android.view.View__Linux Kernel Development details the design and implementation of the Linux kernel, presenting the content in a manner that is beneficial to those writing and developing kernel code, as well as to programmers seeking to better understand the operating system and become more efficient and productive in their coding.></android.view.View__Linux Kernel Development details the design and implementation of the Linux kernel, presenting the content in a manner that is beneficial to those writing and developing kernel code, as well as to programmers seeking to better understand the operating system and become more efficient and productive in their coding.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.></android.view.View__The book details the major subsystems and features of the Linux kernel, including its design, implementation, and interfaces. It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.></android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.><android.view.View__ ></android.view.View__ ><android.view.View__The third edition of Linux Kernel Development includes new and updated material throughout the book:></android.view.View__The third edition of Linux Kernel Development includes new and updated material throughout the book:><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__An all-new chapter on It covers the Linux kernel with both a practical and theoretical eye, which should appeal to readers with a variety of interests and needs.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.></android.view.View__The author, a core kernel developer, shares valuable knowledge and experience on the 2.6 Linux kernel. Specific topics covered include process management, scheduling, time management and timers, the system call interface, memory addressing, memory management, the page cache, the VFS, kernel synchronization, portability concerns, and debugging techniques. This book covers the most interesting features of the Linux 2.6 kernel, including the CFS scheduler, preemptive kernel, block I/O layer, and I/O schedulers.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__The third edition of Linux Kernel Development includes new and updated material throughout the Author></android.view.View__About the Author><android.view.View__Robert Love is an open source programmer, speaker, and author who has been using and contributing to Linux for more than 15 years. He is currently senior software engineer at Google, where he was a member of the team that developed the Android mobile platform’s kernel. Prior to Google, he was Chief Architect, Linux Desktop, at Novell. Before Novell, he was a kernel engineer at MontaVista Software and Ximian.></android.view.View__Robert Love is an open source programmer, speaker, and author who has been using and contributing to Linux for more than 15 years. He is currently senior software engineer at Google, where he was a member of the team that developed the Android mobile platform’s kernel. Prior to Google, he was Chief Architect, Linux Desktop, at Novell. Before Novell, he was a kernel engineer at MontaVista Software and Ximian.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__Love’s kernel projects include the preemptive kernel, the process scheduler, the kernel events layer, inotify,VM enhancements, and several device drivers.></android.view.View__Love’s kernel projects include the preemptive kernel, the process scheduler, the kernel events layer, inotify,VM enhancements, and several device drivers.><android.view.View__¿></android.view.View__¿><android.view.View__He has given numerous talks on and has written multiple articles about the Linux kernel and is a contributing editor for Linux Journal. His other books include Linux System Programming and Linux in a Nutshell.></android.view.View__He has given numerous talks on and has written multiple articles about the Linux kernel and is a contributing editor for Linux Journal. Most RSS apps assume that all posts have a title, even though titles are technically optional in the spec. But I think this is an important distinction because if you think about Twitter-like posting, it should be fast and convenient; making up a title first interrupts the flow of posting.></android.view.View__Not having an RSS item title might take some getting used to for mainstream blogging clients and readers. Most RSS apps assume that all posts have a title, even though titles are technically optional in the spec. But I think this is an important distinction because if you think about Twitter-like posting, it should be fast and convenient; making up a title first interrupts the flow of posting.><android.view.View__The specific rule for post length or which feeds you include can be useful. With many of today’s blogging tools, it is. We must work simultaneously on open standards and on making software that follows those standards as easy to use as possible for everyone.></android.view.View__This might seem like too much work for most people. With many of today’s blogging tools, it is. We must work simultaneously on open standards and on making software that follows those standards as easy to use as possible for everyone.><android.view.View__What we don’t want to do is reinvent the wheel with a new social media-like protocol that isn’t rooted in the web and blogs. Others have tried to come up with new systems for microblogging that don’t use blogs. But the word “blog” is part of “microblog” for a reason. They differ only in length. By using blogs, we get to keep everything that is valuable about blogging. We get to keep existing blog software and IndieWeb-friendly formats.></android.view.View__What we don’t want to do is reinvent the wheel with a new social media-like protocol that isn’t rooted in the web and blogs. Others have tried to come up with new systems for microblogging that don’t use blogs. But the word “blog” is part of “microblog” for a reason. They differ only in length. By using blogs, we get to keep everything that is valuable about blogging. We get to keep existing blog software and IndieWeb-friendly formats.><android.view.View__Blogs are web sites with reverse-chronological posts written by people. The newest posts are always at the top of the web site. They can be news sites, corporate sites, travel sites, photo sites, tech sites. They are often personal, with an individual’s voice. Readers want to keep visiting a blog because there’s a story, unfolding with each post. The passing of time is a fundamental element to what defines a blog.></android.view.View__Blogs are web sites with reverse-chronological posts written by people. The newest posts are always at the top of the web site. They can be news sites, corporate sites, travel sites, photo sites, tech sites. They are often personal, with an individual’s voice. Readers want to keep visiting a blog because there’s a story, unfolding with each post. The passing of time is a fundamental element to what defines a blog.><android.view.View__This emphasis on time is even more obvious for microblogs. Microblogs are blogs with very short posts. Because short posts are easy to write, there are usually more of them. In the case of a microblogging service like Twitter or Micro.blog, friends' posts are combined together in a timeline.></android.view.View__This emphasis on time is even more obvious for microblogs. Microblogs are blogs with very short posts. Because short posts are easy to write, there are usually more of them. In the case of a microblogging service like Twitter or Micro.blog, friends' posts are combined together in a timeline.><android.view.View__In an open platform based on indie microblogs, posts in the timeline come from blogs at the author’s own domain name. This helps distribute content across the web and bypasses the bottleneck of posting only through big social networks, reducing their influence:></android.view.View__In an open platform based on indie microblogs, posts in the timeline come from blogs at the author’s own domain name. This helps distribute content across the web and bypasses the bottleneck of posting only through big social networks, reducing their influence:><android.view.View__Recent posts are placed at the top of the timeline. Older posts fall to the bottom, and eventually drop off. With this focus on the new, some people consider microblogging ephemeral, but it doesn’t have to be.></android.view.View__Recent posts are placed at the top of the timeline. Older posts fall to the bottom, and eventually drop off. With this focus on the new, some people consider microblogging ephemeral, but it doesn’t have to be.><android.view.View__Indie microblogging is about taking ownership of our microblog post content. It’s about reclaiming the definition of what a microblog is from Twitter. Microblogs and social networks are big components of the web — too important to be contained in such a small number of closed, centralized platforms.></android.view.View__Indie microblogging is about taking ownership of our microblog post content. It’s about reclaiming the definition of what a microblog is from Twitter. Microblogs and social networks are big components of the web — too important to be contained in such a small number of closed, centralized platforms.><android.view.View__An indie microblog is a blog that contains short posts at your own domain name. It can be hosted by multiple providers, but it is conceptually independent of any one platform. It’s portable and you control it.></android.view.View__An indie microblog is a blog that contains short posts at your own domain name. function pervade_encrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    while((strpos($iv, '::') !== false) || !$csprng_check) {
        $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);
    }

    $encrypted = openssl_encrypt($data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    $length = strlen($encrypted);
    $hash = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted . $iv, $encryption_key);
    return base64_encode($encrypted . '::' . $length . '-' . $hash . '::' . $iv);
}

function pervade_decrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $exp = explode('::', base64_decode($data), 3);

    if (isset($exp[2])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $length = $exp[1];
        $iv = $exp[2];
        $lenexp = explode('-', $length);

        if (isset($lenexp[1])) {
            $hmac = str_replace($lenexp[0] . '-', '', $length);
            $length = $lenexp[0];
        }
        else {
            $hmac = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        }

        $hashcheck = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        if ((strlen($encrypted_data) == $length) && ($hmac == $hashcheck)) {
            return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
        }
    }
    else if (isset($exp[1])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $iv = $exp[1];
        return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    }
}

I don’t feel like joining the incumbent tone or risk making a neophyte’s impostor syndrome worse than it already is.><android.view.View__The Code in Question></android.view.View__The Code in Question><android.view.View__I have transcribed their source code from the screenshot on Twitter below.></android.view.View__I have transcribed their source code from the screenshot on Twitter below.><android.view.View__<?php

function pervade_encrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    while((strpos($iv, '::') !== false) || !$csprng_check) {
        $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);
    }

    $encrypted = openssl_encrypt($data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    $length = strlen($encrypted);
    $hash = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted . $iv, $encryption_key);
    return base64_encode($encrypted . '::' . $length . '-' . $hash . '::' . $iv);
}

function pervade_decrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $exp = explode('::', base64_decode($data), 3);

    if (isset($exp[2])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $length = $exp[1];
        $iv = $exp[2];
        $lenexp = explode('-', $length);

        if (isset($lenexp[1])) {
            $hmac = str_replace($lenexp[0] . '-', '', $length);
            $length = $lenexp[0];
        }
        else {
            $hmac = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        }

        $hashcheck = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        if ((strlen($encrypted_data) == $length) && ($hmac == $hashcheck)) {
            return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
        }
    }
    else if (isset($exp[1])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $iv = $exp[1];
        return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    }
}
></android.view.View__<?php

function pervade_encrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    while((strpos($iv, '::') !== false) || !$csprng_check) {
        $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);
    }

    $encrypted = openssl_encrypt($data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    $length = strlen($encrypted);
    $hash = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted . $iv, $encryption_key);
    return base64_encode($encrypted . '::' . $length . '-' . $hash . '::' . $iv);
}

function pervade_decrypt($data)
{
    $encryption_key = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
    $exp = explode('::', base64_decode($data), 3);

    if (isset($exp[2])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $length = $exp[1];
        $iv = $exp[2];
        $lenexp = explode('-', $length);

        if (isset($lenexp[1])) {
            $hmac = str_replace($lenexp[0] . '-', '', $length);
            $length = $lenexp[0];
        }
        else {
            $hmac = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        }

        $hashcheck = hash_hmac('sha256', $encrypted_data . $iv, $encryption_key);
        if ((strlen($encrypted_data) == $length) && ($hmac == $hashcheck)) {
            return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
        }
    }
    else if (isset($exp[1])) {
        $encrypted_data = $exp[0];
        $iv = $exp[1];
        return @openssl_decrypt($encrypted_data, 'aes-256-cbc', $encryption_key, 0, $iv);
    }
}

fed into the reader. This lets them perform far more impactful attacks (e.g. padding oracle attacks) than passing information to the writer would reveal (i.e. chosen-plaintext attacks, which overwhelmingly aren’t relevant for protocols that use standard cryptographic algorithms; i.e. AES).></android.view.View__The reasoning is simple: In most threat models, attackers have control over the data being fed into the reader. outputs.></android.view.View__Not that it matters much, since you can just bypass the security control entirely, but == is not the correct way to compare hash function instead><android.view.View__.></android.view.View__.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Confused Deputy Attack></android.view.View__Confused Deputy Attack><android.view.View__Modern encryption-at-rest software allows users to specify some Additional Authenticated Data to prevent ciphertexts from being reordered or replayed in an incorrect context.></android.view.View__Modern encryption-at-rest software allows users to specify some Additional Authenticated Data to prevent ciphertexts from being reordered or replayed in an incorrect context.><android.view.View__The encryption used by Police CyberAlarm doesn’t expose an Additional Authenticated Data mechanism. All fields are also encrypted with the same, static, hard-coded key.></android.view.View__The encryption used by Police CyberAlarm doesn’t expose an Additional Authenticated Data mechanism. All fields are also encrypted with the same, static, hard-coded key.><android.view.View__Imagine a situation where a user’s ZIP code and legal name are encrypted with pervade_encrypt(). You, as an attacker, have access to the database, but not to the source code.></android.view.View__Imagine a situation where a user’s ZIP code and legal name are encrypted with pervade_encrypt(). You, as an attacker, have access to the database, but not to the source code.><android.view.View__You also have a limited access user account that lets you view zip codes in a directory listing, but not legal name.></android.view.View__You also have a limited access user account that lets you view zip codes in a directory listing, but not legal name.><android.view.View__To exploit this, simply overwrite the user’s zip_code field with their encrypted legal_name field and refresh your directory listing. Bob’s your uncle.></android.view.View__To exploit this, simply overwrite the user’s zip_code field with their encrypted legal_name field and refresh your directory listing. Bob’s your uncle.><android.view.View__To mitigate confused deputy attacks, an AEAD construction is recommended.></android.view.View__To mitigate confused deputy attacks, an AEAD construction is recommended.><android.view.View__It’s also possible to implement a custom protocol using AES-CBC and HMAC-SHA256 that includes AAD support, but extra care must be taken to prevent canonicalization attacks.></android.view.View__It’s also possible to implement a custom protocol using AES-CBC and HMAC-SHA256 that includes AAD support, but extra care must be taken to prevent canonicalization attacks.><android.view.View__Other Cryptography Design Flaws></android.view.View__Other Cryptography Design Flaws><android.view.View__Using the Same Key for Multiple Algorithms></android.view.View__Using the Same Key for Multiple Algorithms><android.view.View__Police CyberAlarm uses the same encryption key for both AES-CBC encryption and for HMAC-SHA256. This violates one of the tenets of cryptography protocol design: Never use the same key for more than one purpose.></android.view.View__Police CyberAlarm uses the same encryption key for both AES-CBC encryption and for HMAC-SHA256. This violates one of the tenets of cryptography protocol design: Never use the same key for more than one purpose.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__If you ever fail to uphold this tenet, you introduce ></android.view.View__If you ever fail to uphold this tenet, you introduce ><android.view.View__the risk of related key and cross-protocol attacks in your application></android.view.View__the risk of related key and cross-protocol attacks in your application><android.view.View__. While this isn’t currently known to be exploitable with AES and HMAC, it is very much exploitable in some setups using AES and CBC-MAC.></android.view.View__. While this isn’t currently known to be exploitable with AES and HMAC, it is very much exploitable in some setups using AES and CBC-MAC.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Instead of reusing ></android.view.View__Instead of reusing ><android.view.View__$encryption_key></android.view.View__$encryption_key><android.view.View__ for both></android.view.View__ for both><android.view.View__openssl_encrypt()></android.view.View__openssl_encrypt()><android.view.View__ and ></android.view.View__ and ><android.view.View__hash_hmac()></android.view.View__hash_hmac()><android.view.View__, the correct thing to do is use a key derivation function (i.e. ></android.view.View__, the correct thing to do is use a key derivation function (i.e. ><android.view.View__HKDF></android.view.View__HKDF><android.view.View__) to split the incoming key into two different keys: One for encryption, the other for authentication.></android.view.View__) to split the incoming key into two different keys: One for encryption, the other for authentication.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__$ikm = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);
$encryption_key = hash_hkdf('sha256', $ikm, 32, 'encryption');
$hmac_key = hash_hkdf('sha256', $ikm, 32, 'hmac');
></android.view.View__$ikm = (defined('NEW_PERVADE_KEY') ? NEW_PERVADE_KEY : PERVADE_KEY);

><android.view.View__OpenSSL CSPRNG Check Infinite Loop></android.view.View__OpenSSL CSPRNG Check Infinite Loop><android.view.View__If this code sets $csprng_check to false, you will DoS your own application.></android.view.View__If this code sets $csprng_check to false, you will DoS your own application.><android.view.View__$iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

    $iv = openssl_random_pseudo_bytes(openssl_cipher_iv_length('aes-256-cbc'), $csprng_check);

><android.view.View__The reason is subtle: $csprng_check is kind of a useless feature. It’s vestigal to OpenSSL’s RAND_pseudo_bytes()API. In PHP, if the value is ever set to false, it will continue to be false for the duration of the process.></android.view.View__The reason is subtle: $csprng_check is kind of a useless feature. It’s vestigal to OpenSSL’s RAND_pseudo_bytes()API. In PHP, if the value is ever set to false, it will continue to be false for the duration of the process.><android.view.View__It’s also a superfluous check: If OpenSSL’s RNG is insecure (i.e. the Debian weak key debacle), would you trust OpenSSL to be aware of its insecurity?></android.view.View__It’s also a superfluous check: If OpenSSL’s RNG is insecure (i.e. the Debian weak key debacle), would you trust OpenSSL to be aware of its insecurity?><android.view.View__><android.view.View__You want random_bytes() here.></android.view.View__You want random_bytes() here.><android.view.View__ For PHP 5,></android.view.View__ For PHP 5,><android.view.View__paragonie/random_compat></android.view.View__paragonie/random_compat><android.view.View__.></android.view.View__.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__With random_bytes(), if the RNG fails, an Exception will be thrown. This will fail closed and prevent the application from proceeding with insecure randomness.></android.view.View__With random_bytes(), if the RNG fails, an Exception will be thrown. This will fail closed and prevent the application from proceeding with insecure randomness.><android.view.View__Summary></android.view.View__Summary><android.view.View__The cryptography used by Police CyberAlarm is not secure and should be replaced with something more secure.></android.view.View__The cryptography used by Police CyberAlarm is not secure and should be replaced with something more secure.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__A much better implementation is ext/sodium (PHP 7.2+) or ></android.view.View__A much better implementation is ext/sodium (PHP 7.2+) or ><android.view.View__paragonie/sodium_compat></android.view.View__paragonie/sodium_compat><android.view.View__ (PHP 5.2+) provides ></android.view.View__ (PHP 5.2+) provides ><android.view.View__the NaCl/libsodium default></android.view.View__the NaCl/libsodium default><android.view.View__ that other experts recommend. Partial functions add cognitive overhead, they are harder to reason about and can lead to runtime errors. Some examples:', ix=''}, comp{id=716, n='android.view.View', t='', d='// example 1: sum of the list// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value// example 2: get the first item in list// first :: [A] -> Aconstfirst=a=>a[0]first([42])// 42first([])// undefined// or even worse:first([[42]])[0]// 42first([])[0]// Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined// example 3: repeat function N times// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded', ix=''}, comp{id=717, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Dealing with partial functions', ix=''}, comp{id=718, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=719, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Partial functions are dangerous as they need to be treated with great caution. You might get an unexpected (wrong) result or run into runtime errors. Sometimes a partial function might not return at all. Being aware of and treating all these edge cases accordingly can become very tedious. Fortunately a partial function can be converted to a regular (or total) one. We can provide default values or use guards to deal with inputs for which the (previously) partial function is undefined. Utilizing the ', ix=''}, comp{id=720, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Option', ix=''}, comp{id=721, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' type, we can yield either ', ix=''}, comp{id=722, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Some(value)', ix=''}, comp{id=723, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' or ', ix=''}, comp{id=724, n='android.view.View', t='', d='None', ix=''}, comp{id=725, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' where we would otherwise have behaved unexpectedly:', ix=''}, comp{id=726, n='android.view.View', t='', d='// example 1: sum of the list// we can provide default value so it will always return result// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b,0)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// 0// example 2: get the first item in list// change result to Option// first :: [A] -> Option Aconstfirst=a=>a.length ? Some(a[0]) : None()first([42]).map(a=>console.log(a))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a))// console.log won't execute at all// our previous worst casefirst([[42]]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// won't execte, so we won't have error here// more of that, you will know by function return type (Option)// that you should use `.map` method to access the data and you will never forget// to check your input because such check become built-in into the function// example 3: repeat function N times// we should make function always terminate by changing conditions:// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n>0&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// won't execute anything', ix=''}, comp{id=727, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Making your partial functions total ones, these kinds of runtime errors can be prevented. Always returning a value will also make for code that is both easier to maintain as well as to reason about.', ix=''}, comp{id=728, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Functional Programming Libraries in In programming, typically types act as the objects and functions as morphisms.><android.view.View__To be a valid category 3 rules must be met:></android.view.View__To be a valid category 3 rules must be met:><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__There must be an identity morphism that maps an object to itself. In functional languages, this allows for structures like infinite lists, which would not normally be available in an imperative language where the sequencing of commands is significant.></android.view.View__Lazy evaluation is a call-by-need evaluation mechanism that delays the evaluation of an expression until its value is needed. However, there's a difference:><android.view.View__In paramorphism, your reducer's arguments are the current value, the reduction of all previous values, and the list of values that formed that reduction.></android.view.View__In paramorphism, your reducer's arguments are the current value, the reduction of all previous values, and the list of values that formed that reduction.><android.view.View__// Obviously not safe for lists containing `undefined`,// but good enough to make the point.constpara=(reducer,accumulator,elements)=>{if(elements.length===0){returnaccumulator}consthead=elements[0]consttail=elements.slice(1)returnreducer(head,tail,para(reducer,accumulator,tail))}constsuffixes=list=>para((x,xs,suffxs)=>[xs, ...suffxs],[],list)suffixes([1,2,3,4,5])// [[2, 3, 4, 5], [3, 4, 5], [4, 5], [5], []]></android.view.View__// Obviously not safe for lists containing `undefined`,// but good enough to make the point.constpara=(reducer,accumulator,elements)=>{if(elements.length===0){returnaccumulator}consthead=elements[0]consttail=elements.slice(1)returnreducer(head,tail,para(reducer,accumulator,tail))}constsuffixes=list=>para((x,xs,suffxs)=>[xs, ...suffxs],[],list)suffixes([1,2,3,4,5])// [[2, 3, 4, 5], [3, 4, 5], [4, 5], [5], []]><android.view.View__The third parameter in the reducer (in the above example, [x, ... xs]) is kind of like having a history of what got you to your current acc value.></android.view.View__The third parameter in the reducer (in the above example, [x, ... xs]) is kind of like having a history of what got you to your current acc value.><android.view.View__Apomorphism></android.view.View__Apomorphism><android.view.View__it's the opposite of paramorphism, just as anamorphism is the opposite of catamorphism. Partial functions add cognitive overhead, they are harder to reason about and can lead to runtime errors. Some examples:></android.view.View__ which is not defined for all arguments - it might return an unexpected result or may never terminate. Partial functions add cognitive overhead, they are harder to reason about and can lead to runtime errors. Some examples:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value// example 2: get the first item in list// first :: [A] -> Aconstfirst=a=>a[0]first([42])// 42first([])// undefined// or even worse:first([[42]])[0]// 42first([])[0]// Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined// example 3: repeat function N times// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded></android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// TypeError: Reduce of empty array with no initial value// example 2: get the first item in list// first :: [A] -> Aconstfirst=a=>a[0]first([42])// 42first([])// undefined// or even worse:first([[42]])[0]// 42first([])[0]// Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined// example 3: repeat function N times// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded><android.view.View__Dealing with partial functions></android.view.View__Dealing with partial functions><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Partial functions are dangerous as they need to be treated with great caution. You might get an unexpected (wrong) result or run into runtime errors. Sometimes a partial function might not return at all. Being aware of and treating all these edge cases accordingly can become very tedious. Fortunately a partial function can be converted to a regular (or total) one. We can provide default values or use guards to deal with inputs for which the (previously) partial function is undefined. Utilizing the ></android.view.View__Partial functions are dangerous as they need to be treated with great caution. You might get an unexpected (wrong) result or run into runtime errors. Sometimes a partial function might not return at all. Being aware of and treating all these edge cases accordingly can become very tedious. Fortunately a partial function can be converted to a regular (or total) one. We can provide default values or use guards to deal with inputs for which the (previously) partial function is undefined. Utilizing the ><android.view.View__Option></android.view.View__Option><android.view.View__ type, we can yield either ></android.view.View__ type, we can yield either ><android.view.View__Some(value)></android.view.View__Some(value)><android.view.View__ or ></android.view.View__ or ><android.view.View__None></android.view.View__None><android.view.View__ where we would otherwise have behaved unexpectedly:></android.view.View__ where we would otherwise have behaved unexpectedly:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// we can provide default value so it will always return result// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b,0)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// 0// example 2: get the first item in list// change result to Option// first :: [A] -> Option Aconstfirst=a=>a.length ? Some(a[0]) : None()first([42]).map(a=>console.log(a))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a))// console.log won't execute at all// our previous worst casefirst([[42]]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// won't execte, so we won't have error here// more of that, you will know by function return type (Option)// that you should use `.map` method to access the data and you will never forget// to check your input because such check become built-in into the function// example 3: repeat function N times// we should make function always terminate by changing conditions:// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n>0&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// won't execute anything></android.view.View__// example 1: sum of the list// we can provide default value so it will always return result// sum :: [Number] -> Numberconstsum=arr=>arr.reduce((a,b)=>a+b,0)sum([1,2,3])// 6sum([])// 0// example 2: get the first item in list// change result to Option// first :: [A] -> Option Aconstfirst=a=>a.length ? Some(a[0]) : None()first([42]).map(a=>console.log(a))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a))// console.log won't execute at all// our previous worst casefirst([[42]]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// 42first([]).map(a=>console.log(a[0]))// won't execte, so we won't have error here// more of that, you will know by function return type (Option)// that you should use `.map` method to access the data and you will never forget// to check your input because such check become built-in into the function// example 3: repeat function N times// we should make function always terminate by changing conditions:// times :: Number -> (Number -> Number) -> Numberconsttimes=n=>fn=>n>0&&(fn(n),times(n-1)(fn))times(3)(console.log)// 3// 2// 1times(-1)(console.log)// won't execute anything><android.view.View__Making your partial functions total ones, these kinds of runtime errors can be prevented. Always returning a value will also make for code that is both easier to maintain as well as to reason about.></android.view.View__Making your partial functions total ones, these kinds of runtime errors can be prevented. Always returning a value will also make for code that is both easier to maintain as well as to reason about.><android.view.View__Functional Programming Libraries in It's fully gamified, so beginners are called "students" and more advanced players are called "builders". To become a "builder" you need to pass some trials. The "builders" probably have their own challenges (not sure, my son is still a student), in any case, they behave like teachers. So a student will find a builder who will give them instructions, and guide them through more and more complex designs.></android.view.View__On this server players learn how to build logic gates, and mix them so they eventually build CPUs. So a student will find a builder who will give them instructions, and guide them through more and more complex designs.><android.view.View__So, yesterday my son had no idea what XOR or NAND is, and today he already built a 4-bit adder, and has dreams of building an ALU.></android.view.View__So, yesterday my son had no idea what XOR or NAND is, and today he already built a 4-bit adder, and has dreams of building an ALU.><android.view.View__I'm quite excited to be honest. I keep an eye on what he’s doing there, which is quite easy, as he just won’t stop talking about it. It’s also an opportunity for me to teach him, but in a way that he finds exciting. If one day I had decided to teach him XOR or NAND, he would’ve found it very boring. This way, he comes to me with questions, and I can pick up a piece of paper and show him what a truth table is, and he soaks it up. Take her to visit woods, hills (with good views), rock formations, streams, lakes, old buildings open the public. Go to museums. Borrow a dog. Mom's attempts to do so are met with less enthusiasm.><android.view.View__----></android.view.View__----><android.view.View__Thaaat said: parenting so far has confirmed the story about the Oedipus complex. In plain words, it's like this: mom can't give him her full attention; the world and society and large steal her from him. Luckily, the baby learns to personify all this stuff into dad -- it's dad who steals mommy. This is lucky because he can aspire to be me, while "society at large" is enough to drive anyone insane. This is very very clear in this family: kid wants to be with his mom, often alone with her; but also: kid wants to be like me. He attentively watches me as I dress, and enjoys enormously the homologies (hey, let's all put on socks!). Even when it comes to daddy's "no" -- this is understandable, the overarching ways of the world are not. (Jacques Lacan has this pun where "le non du pere" becomes "le nom du pere" -- baby will have my name, this is the heart of fathering.)></android.view.View__Thaaat said: parenting so far has confirmed the story about the Oedipus complex. In plain words, it's like this: mom can't give him her full attention; the world and society and large steal her from him. Luckily, the baby learns to personify all this stuff into dad -- it's dad who steals mommy. This is lucky because he can aspire to be me, while "society at large" is enough to drive anyone insane. This is very very clear in this family: kid wants to be with his mom, often alone with her; but also: kid wants to be like me. He attentively watches me as I dress, and enjoys enormously the homologies (hey, let's all put on socks!). Even when it comes to daddy's "no" -- this is understandable, the overarching ways of the world are not. (Jacques Lacan has this pun where "le non du pere" becomes "le nom du pere" -- baby will have my name, this is the heart of fathering.)><android.view.View__><android.view.View__reply></android.view.View__reply></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__vote?id=31978026&how=up&goto=item%3Fid%3D31965616></android.view.View__vote?id=31978026&how=up&goto=item%3Fid%3D31965616><android.view.View__><android.view.View__stevekemp></android.view.View__stevekemp><android.view.View__11 minutes ago></android.view.View__11 minutes ago><android.view.View__| ></android.view.View__| ><android.view.View__ | ></android.view.View__ | ><android.view.View__ | ></android.view.View__ | ><android.view.View__[–]></android.view.View__[–]></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__

I ended up getting the official arduino starter kit and the Elagoo (?) kit Rober mentions in the class list. The Elagoo one is more versatile, but they complemented each other. is
   type A_Type is array (Natural range 1 .. 5) of Natural;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   is
   begin
      for I in A'Range loop
         for J in A'Range loop
            if A (I) < A (J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
           end if;
         end loop;
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type;
begin
   for I in A'Range loop 
     A (I) := A'Last - I + 1;
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;', ix=''}, comp{id=81, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=82, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Start small (simple small data types, a single subprogram)', ix=''}, comp{id=83, n='android.view.View', t='', d='
', ix=''}, comp{id=84, n='android.view.View', t='', d='When I read the tweet and all the replies, I admit I felt compassion for old me (well, young me), even though I saw other people admitting they’d come up with this sorting algorithm once upon a time. I wondered whether applying modern tech (other than having a sorting algorithm in the standard library and knowing about it…) blindly would comfort such a developer in his or her “wrong” version. I decided to launch myself a challenge: proving the algorithm using SPARK, without looking at the proof in the paper. Should be easy enough, right (famous last words)?', ix=''}, comp{id=85, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=86, n='android.view.View', t='', d='gamechanger', ix=''}, comp{id=87, n='android.view.View', t='', d='I fired up the ultimate Ada IDE (vim) and just copy-pasted the old code, compiled it (gnatmake -gnatA stupid_sort.adb) and ran it (through gdb to get the content of A after Sort returns). It works, for that input.', ix=''}, comp{id=88, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Start with a passing test', ix=''}, comp{id=89, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=90, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Then I wanted to prove that Sort sorts all possible arrays so I added the SPARK pixie dust:', ix=''}, comp{id=91, n='android.view.View', t='', d='
', ix=''}, comp{id=92, n='android.view.View', t='', d='
', ix=''}, comp{id=93, n='android.view.View', t='', d='procedure Stupid_Sort with SPARK_Mode => On', ix=''}, comp{id=94, n='android.view.View', t='', d='and the necessary post-condition for Sort:', ix=''}, comp{id=95, n='android.view.View', t='', d='procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)

   with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)', ix=''}, comp{id=148, n='android.view.View', t='', d='That’s true, but not sufficient. Indeed, all the provers know about variable A after a call to Swap (since this parameter is modified in Swap) is what the postcondition of Swap says about it. And… it says nothing about all the values of A outside of indexes I and J! So there is no chance that GNATprove will be able to prove our sorting code.', ix=''}, comp{id=149, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=150, n='android.view.View', t='', d='This need to identify what has changed during a call with enough precision is known as the', ix=''}, comp{id=151, n='android.view.View', t='', d='frame condition', ix=''}, comp{id=152, n='android.view.View', t='', d=', and it’s a typical beginner’s mistake to forget it.    with Post => A = (A’Old with delta I => A(J)’Old, J => A(I)’Old)', ix=''}, comp{id=154, n='android.view.View', t='', d='which states exactly the content of A after a call to Swap.', ix=''}, comp{id=155, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Beware the frame condition', ix=''}, comp{id=156, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Ironically, you get the same result if you don’t specify a postcondition at all on Swap, because GNATprove will inline the call in that case! Inlining of calls and unrolling of loops are powerful techniques for automating the proof of programs, without the need for a user to specify contracts and loop invariants. But as usual with automation, the risk is that, when the situation gets more complex, automation fails and the user is left with a complex situation that she does not understand (a.k.a. the curse of automation). Loop unrolling explains why Lionel was initially "feeling lucky!" with Z3 proving the postcondition of Sort for small array sizes, without having to write loop invariants. But the curse of automation stroke back when increasing the array size, as the loops are not unrolled anymore, or the unrolling leads to unmanageable formulas for automatic provers.', ix=''}, comp{id=157, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=158, n='android.view.View', t='', d='One way to remain aware of the choices in terms of automation made by GNATprove is to use the switch --info which outputs such information:', ix=''}, comp{id=159, n='android.view.View', t='', d='
', ix=''}, comp{id=160, n='android.view.View', t='', d='stupid_sort.adb:11:14: info: local subprogram "Sort" only analyzed in the context of calls

type A_Type is array (I_Type) of Natural;', ix=''}, comp{id=167, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Define suitable types with the tightest constraints', ix=''}, comp{id=168, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Types are the best specifications, because you get their properties everywhere a value of the type is used, without having to repeat the properties in assertions, preconditions, etc.', ix=''}, comp{id=169, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Then, I defined expression functions for the important properties used in the article: that the array over a given range is sorted, and that the maximum of the array over a given range is at a given index.', ix=''}, comp{id=170, n='android.view.View', t='', d='function Sorted (A : A_Type; From : I_Type; To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean 
is
   (for all I in From .. To =>
      (for all J in I .. To =>
         A(I) <= A(J)));

function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A, From, To : I_Type) return Boolean 
is
  (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
with
  Pre => M in From .. To;', ix=''}, comp{id=171, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Define suitable expression functions for important properties', ix=''}, comp{id=172, n='android.view.View', t='', d='In general, it’s better to give a name to important properties that will be used multiple times in specifications, assertions and ghost code, because it makes the specification and proof more readable, and because it can help automatic provers. Here, it’s all the more helpful for automatic provers because it isolates quantifiers “for all”.', ix=''}, comp{id=173, n='android.view.View', t='', d='The form of these properties is also quite important. Instead of using the natural expression of sortedness as “every element is less or equal to the next”, I have expressed it as the equivalent transitive closure of this property, that is, “every element is less or equal to every element that follows”. That makes a big difference for automatic provers, as establishing the latter from the former requires inductive reasoning, which automatic provers are poor at, while the former is immediately deduced from the latter.', ix=''}, comp{id=174, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Similarly, I could have defined Is_Max as a function that takes as input the maximum Max of the array over a given range, instead of the index M of the maximum, and computes the conjunction:', ix=''}, comp{id=175, n='android.view.View', t='', d='(for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= Max)
   and then
(for some M in From .. To => Max = A (M))', ix=''}, comp{id=176, n='android.view.View', t='', d='But this uses an existential quantification “for some” which is hard to establish for automatic provers, as this requires exhibiting the “witness” index M here. So I went for the definition that did not require an existential quantification, by passing the index M as parameter instead.', ix=''}, comp{id=177, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Use idiomatic definitions of properties that help automatic provers', ix=''}, comp{id=178, n='android.view.View', t='', d='With these definitions, the loop invariant of the external loop can be expressed very easily, based on the properties of that loop described in the article:', ix=''}, comp{id=179, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));', ix=''}, comp{id=180, n='android.view.View', t='', d='It gets a bit trickier for the internal loop, as the explanations in the article in terms of values of K before and after I cannot be directly translated into loop invariants. Plus the article talks of going from index I to index I+1 while the code goes from index I-1 and index I (when expressing the loop invariant). That’s where I tried out various loop invariants in my head, with the support of pen-and-paper to understand how the algorithm really worked. And it went 💡 the array stayed sorted at every iteration of the internal loop for all indexes lower than I!', ix=''}, comp{id=181, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));', ix=''}, comp{id=182, n='android.view.View', t='', d='And during the internal loop, the maximum value over the whole array was either located at index I-1 (at the beginning of the iteration) or at index I (after getting to iteration J = I-1):', ix=''}, comp{id=183, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant
   (declare
       M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
    begin
       Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last));', ix=''}, comp{id=184, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Use pen-and-paper to really understand the code that you want to prove', ix=''}, comp{id=185, n='android.view.View', t='', d='It’s all too easy to “understand” that something works by going through the steps of an explanation/demonstration (like in the article), without being able to really understand why it works. Proof requires us to understand why it works.', ix=''}, comp{id=186, n='android.view.View', t='', d='As GNATprove could not prove the loop invariant of the inner loop, even at level 4 (all provers get called at that level, with a substantial timeout of 60 seconds per check), I tried running the program through its test with assertions enabled, and… the loop invariant failed at runtime! No wonder GNATprove could not prove it.', ix=''}, comp{id=187, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Execute assertions during tests to help debug them', ix=''}, comp{id=188, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Just looking at the failing loop invariant, I realized that it could not be true during the first iteration of the loop, where we have not yet identified the maximum value of the array. So I added a special case for I=A’First:', ix=''}, comp{id=189, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant
  (if I = A'First then
     Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
   else
      (declare
          M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
       begin
          Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));', ix=''}, comp{id=190, n='android.view.View', t='', d='But the test was still failing at runtime! This time, I ran the test in the debugger (gdb inside GNAT Studio), to display values of all variables when hitting the failing loop invariant. That was a case of off-by-one error, the test “J < I” in the definition of constant M should be “J < I-1”. With that, the test was running without error.', ix=''}, comp{id=191, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Tip: Debug failing assertions by running tests with assertions in the debugger', ix=''}, comp{id=192, n='android.view.View', t='', d='I reran GNATprove on the code. It reported cases of runtime errors when calling functions Sorted/Is_Max, which I fixed. But GNATprove could still not prove the loop invariant of the internal loop stating that A remained sorted from A’First to I-1. I read again the explanations in the article, which confirmed that it was true. Yet it was not proved. So I looked at the code, to see how the loop invariant at iteration J can be deduced from the loop invariant at iteration J-1 and the execution of the current iteration. And it was not provable! Because we were missing the information that, up to value J=I-1, the value at index I is greater than all values seen so far:', ix=''}, comp{id=193, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Loop_Invariant

', ix=''}, comp{id=258, n='android.view.View', t='', d='pragma Ada_2022;

procedure Stupid_Sort with SPARK_Mode => On
is
   type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. Integer'Last;
   subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
   type A_Type is array (I_Type range <>) of Natural;

   function Sorted (A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
      (for all I in From .. To =>
         (for all J in I .. To =>
            A(I) <= A(J)))
   with
     Pre => From in A'Range
       and then To <= A'Last;

   function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
     (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
   with
     Pre => M in From .. To
       and then From in A'Range
       and then To in A'Range;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   with
     Post => (if A'Length > 0 then Sorted (A, A'First, A'Last))
   is
   begin
      for I in A'range loop
         for J in A'range loop
            if A(I) < A(J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A(I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
            end if;

            pragma Loop_Invariant (if J < I then A(J) <= A(I));
            pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I-1));
            pragma Loop_Invariant
              (if I = A'First then
                Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
              else
                (declare
                   M : constant I_Type := (if J < I-1 then I-1 else I);
                 begin
                   Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));
         end loop;

         pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
         pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type (1 .. 1000);
begin
   for I in A'Range loop
     A (I) := Integer (A'Last - I + 1);
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;', ix=''}, comp{id=259, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=260, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Posted in ', ix=''}, comp{id=261, n='android.view.View', t='', d='#SPARK', ix=''}, comp{id=262, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    ', ix=''}, comp{id=263, n='android.view.View', t='', d='#Proof', ix=''}, comp{id=264, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    ', ix=''}, comp{id=265, n='android.view.View', t='', d='#Algorithms', ix=''}, comp{id=266, n='android.view.View', t='', d='   ', ix=''}, comp{id=267, n='android.view.View', t='', d='About ', ix=''}, comp{id=268, n='android.view.View', t='', d='About ', ix=''}, comp{id=269, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Yannick Moy', ix=''}, comp{id=270, n='android.widget.Image', t='', d='Yannick Moy', ix=''}, comp{id=271, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=272, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Yannick Moy is Static Analysis Lead at AdaCore. 2022><android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Sorting algorithms are to computer science what “Hello World!” is to programming. A way for beginners to get their hands dirty. Which also means that most programmers don’t write “Hello World!” programs past their studies, and computer scientists don’t look at sorting algorithms past their PhD.></android.view.View__Sorting algorithms are to computer science what “Hello World!” is to programming. A way for beginners to get their hands dirty. Which also means that most programmers don’t write “Hello World!” programs past their studies, and computer scientists don’t look at sorting algorithms past their PhD.><android.view.View__Which made it surprising that a new “interesting” sorting algorithm was published at the end of 2021, whose appeal drew attention from both computer scientists and programmers. Despite a hopeful start, this ended up badly. As a SPARK expert thus contacted to help with the challenge, one of us (Yannick) took it as a way to show how functional proof should be approached in SPARK. Including some false starts, this ended up well (and under an hour). This is the story of this challenge, and the tips we think are important to share with those who aim at functional proof with SPARK.></android.view.View__As an expert user of Ada, and an anecdotal user of SPARK, one of us (Lionel) took it as a challenge to try some functional proof with SPARK. Despite a hopeful start, this ended up badly. Including some false starts, this ended up well (and under an hour). is
   type A_Type is array (Natural range 1 .. 5) of Natural;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   is
   begin
      for I in A'Range loop
         for J in A'Range loop
            if A (I) < A (J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
           end if;
         end loop;
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type;
begin
   for I in A'Range loop 
     A (I) := A'Last - I + 1;
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;></android.view.View__procedure Stupid_Sort
is
   type A_Type is array (Natural range 1 .. 5) of Natural;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   is
   begin
      for I in A'Range loop
         for J in A'Range loop
            if A (I) < A (J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
           end if;
         end loop;
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type;
begin
   for I in A'Range loop 
     A (I) := A'Last - I + 1;
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Tip: Start small (simple small data types, a single subprogram)></android.view.View__Tip: Start small (simple small data types, a single subprogram)><android.view.View__
></android.view.View__
></android.view.View__><android.view.View__When I read the tweet and all the replies, I admit I felt compassion for old me (well, young me), even though I saw other people admitting they’d come up with this sorting algorithm once upon a time. I wondered whether applying modern tech (other than having a sorting algorithm in the standard library and knowing about it…) blindly would comfort such a developer in his or her “wrong” version. I decided to launch myself a challenge: proving the algorithm using SPARK, without looking at the proof in the paper. Should be easy enough, right (famous last words)?></android.view.View__When I read the tweet and all the replies, I admit I felt compassion for old me (well, young me), even though I saw other people admitting they’d come up with this sorting algorithm once upon a time. I wondered whether applying modern tech (other than having a sorting algorithm in the standard library and knowing about it…) blindly would comfort such a developer in his or her “wrong” version. I decided to launch myself a challenge: proving the algorithm using SPARK, without looking at the proof in the paper. Should be easy enough, right (famous last words)?><android.view.View__><android.view.View__gamechanger></android.view.View__gamechanger></android.view.View__><android.view.View__I fired up the ultimate Ada IDE (vim) and just copy-pasted the old code, compiled it (gnatmake -gnatA stupid_sort.adb) and ran it (through gdb to get the content of A after Sort returns). It works, for that input.></android.view.View__I fired up the ultimate Ada IDE (vim) and just copy-pasted the old code, compiled it (gnatmake -gnatA stupid_sort.adb) and ran it (through gdb to get the content of A after Sort returns). It works, for that input.><android.view.View__Tip: Start with a passing test></android.view.View__Tip: Start with a passing test><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Then I wanted to prove that Sort sorts all possible arrays so I added the SPARK pixie dust:></android.view.View__Then I wanted to prove that Sort sorts all possible arrays so I added the SPARK pixie dust:><android.view.View__

   with Post => (for all J in A'First ..    for Main use ("stupid_sort.adb");
   for Source_Files use ("stupid_sort.adb");

   package Compiler is
      for Switches ("Ada") use
           ("-gnata",     -- enable assertions and runtime checks
            "-gnat2022",  -- for newest forms of expressions in Ada 2022
            "-g", "-O0"); -- for debugging
    end Compiler;

end Stupid_Sort;></android.view.View__project Stupid_Sort is

   for Main use ("stupid_sort.adb");
   for Source_Files use ("stupid_sort.adb");

   package Compiler is
      for Switches ("Ada") use
           ("-gnata",     -- enable assertions and runtime checks
            "-gnat2022",  -- for newest forms of expressions in Ada 2022
            "-g", "-O0"); -- for debugging
    end Compiler;

end Stupid_Sort;><android.view.View__And on I went:></android.view.View__And on I went:><android.view.View__> gnatprove -Pstupid_sort.gpr -j0

  with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)
is
   Tmp : constant Natural := A (I);
begin
   A (I) := A (J);
   A (J) := Tmp;
end Swap;></android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)

   A (I) := A (J);

Remember the postcondition he wrote for Swap:><android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)></android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A (J) = A'Old (I) and A (I) = A'Old (J)><android.view.View__That’s true, but not sufficient. Indeed, all the provers know about variable A after a call to Swap (since this parameter is modified in Swap) is what the postcondition of Swap says about it. And… it says nothing about all the values of A outside of indexes I and J! So there is no chance that GNATprove will be able to prove our sorting code.></android.view.View__That’s true, but not sufficient. Indeed, all the provers know about variable A after a call to Swap (since this parameter is modified in Swap) is what the postcondition of Swap says about it. And… it says nothing about all the values of A outside of indexes I and J! So there is no chance that GNATprove will be able to prove our sorting code.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__This need to identify what has changed during a call with enough precision is known as the></android.view.View__This need to identify what has changed during a call with enough precision is known as the><android.view.View__frame condition></android.view.View__frame condition><android.view.View__, and it’s a typical beginner’s mistake to forget it. Here, a suitable postcondition would be:></android.view.View__, and it’s a typical beginner’s mistake to forget it. Here, a suitable postcondition would be:></android.view.View__><android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A = (A’Old with delta I => A(J)’Old, J => A(I)’Old)></android.view.View__procedure Swap (A : in out A_Type; I : A_Index_Type; J : A_Index_Type)
   with Post => A = (A’Old with delta I => A(J)’Old, J => A(I)’Old)><android.view.View__which states exactly the content of A after a call to Swap.></android.view.View__which states exactly the content of A after a call to Swap.><android.view.View__Tip: Beware the frame condition></android.view.View__Tip: Beware the frame condition><android.view.View__Ironically, you get the same result if you don’t specify a postcondition at all on Swap, because GNATprove will inline the call in that case! Inlining of calls and unrolling of loops are powerful techniques for automating the proof of programs, without the need for a user to specify contracts and loop invariants. But as usual with automation, the risk is that, when the situation gets more complex, automation fails and the user is left with a complex situation that she does not understand (a.k.a. the curse of automation). Loop unrolling explains why Lionel was initially "feeling lucky!" with Z3 proving the postcondition of Sort for small array sizes, without having to write loop invariants. But the curse of automation stroke back when increasing the array size, as the loops are not unrolled anymore, or the unrolling leads to unmanageable formulas for automatic provers.></android.view.View__Ironically, you get the same result if you don’t specify a postcondition at all on Swap, because GNATprove will inline the call in that case! Inlining of calls and unrolling of loops are powerful techniques for automating the proof of programs, without the need for a user to specify contracts and loop invariants. But as usual with automation, the risk is that, when the situation gets more complex, automation fails and the user is left with a complex situation that she does not understand (a.k.a. the curse of automation). Loop unrolling explains why Lionel was initially "feeling lucky!" with Z3 proving the postcondition of Sort for small array sizes, without having to write loop invariants. But the curse of automation stroke back when increasing the array size, as the loops are not unrolled anymore, or the unrolling leads to unmanageable formulas for automatic provers.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__One way to remain aware of the choices in terms of automation made by GNATprove is to use the switch --info which outputs such information:></android.view.View__One way to remain aware of the choices in terms of automation made by GNATprove is to use the switch --info which outputs such information:><android.view.View__

More on that later.></android.view.View__Well, at least I thought I understood the algorithm. More on that later.><android.view.View__I started by defining suitable types for the index of the array, one being slightly larger than the other, in order to accommodate empty ranges of values (when we start the iteration):></android.view.View__I started by defining suitable types for the index of the array, one being slightly larger than the other, in order to accommodate empty ranges of values (when we start the iteration):><android.view.View__type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. 5;
subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
type A_Type is array (I_Type) of Natural;></android.view.View__type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. 5;
subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
type A_Type is array (I_Type) of Natural;><android.view.View__Tip: Define suitable types with the tightest constraints></android.view.View__Tip: Define suitable types with the tightest constraints><android.view.View__Types are the best specifications, because you get their properties everywhere a value of the type is used, without having to repeat the properties in assertions, preconditions, etc.></android.view.View__Types are the best specifications, because you get their properties everywhere a value of the type is used, without having to repeat the properties in assertions, preconditions, etc.><android.view.View__Then, I defined expression functions for the important properties used in the article: that the array over a given range is sorted, and that the maximum of the array over a given range is at a given index.></android.view.View__Then, I defined expression functions for the important properties used in the article: that the array over a given range is sorted, and that the maximum of the array over a given range is at a given index.><android.view.View__function Sorted (A : A_Type; From : I_Type; To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean 
is
   (for all I in From .. To =>
      (for all J in I .. To =>
         A(I) <= A(J)));

function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A, From, To : I_Type) return Boolean 
is
  (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
with
  Pre => M in From .. To;></android.view.View__function Sorted (A : A_Type; From : I_Type; To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean 
is
   (for all I in From .. To =>
      (for all J in I .. To =>
         A(I) <= A(J)));

function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A, From, To : I_Type) return Boolean 
is
  (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
with
  Pre => M in From .. To;><android.view.View__Tip: Define suitable expression functions for important properties></android.view.View__Tip: Define suitable expression functions for important properties><android.view.View__In general, it’s better to give a name to important properties that will be used multiple times in specifications, assertions and ghost code, because it makes the specification and proof more readable, and because it can help automatic provers. Here, it’s all the more helpful for automatic provers because it isolates quantifiers “for all”.></android.view.View__In general, it’s better to give a name to important properties that will be used multiple times in specifications, assertions and ghost code, because it makes the specification and proof more readable, and because it can help automatic provers. Here, it’s all the more helpful for automatic provers because it isolates quantifiers “for all”.><android.view.View__The form of these properties is also quite important. Instead of using the natural expression of sortedness as “every element is less or equal to the next”, I have expressed it as the equivalent transitive closure of this property, that is, “every element is less or equal to every element that follows”. That makes a big difference for automatic provers, as establishing the latter from the former requires inductive reasoning, which automatic provers are poor at, while the former is immediately deduced from the latter.></android.view.View__The form of these properties is also quite important. Instead of using the natural expression of sortedness as “every element is less or equal to the next”, I have expressed it as the equivalent transitive closure of this property, that is, “every element is less or equal to every element that follows”. That makes a big difference for automatic provers, as establishing the latter from the former requires inductive reasoning, which automatic provers are poor at, while the former is immediately deduced from the latter.><android.view.View__Similarly, I could have defined Is_Max as a function that takes as input the maximum Max of the array over a given range, instead of the index M of the maximum, and computes the conjunction:></android.view.View__Similarly, I could have defined Is_Max as a function that takes as input the maximum Max of the array over a given range, instead of the index M of the maximum, and computes the conjunction:><android.view.View__(for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= Max)
   and then
(for some M in From .. To => Max = A (M))></android.view.View__(for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= Max)
   and then
(for some M in From .. To => Max = A (M))><android.view.View__But this uses an existential quantification “for some” which is hard to establish for automatic provers, as this requires exhibiting the “witness” index M here. So I went for the definition that did not require an existential quantification, by passing the index M as parameter instead.></android.view.View__But this uses an existential quantification “for some” which is hard to establish for automatic provers, as this requires exhibiting the “witness” index M here. So I went for the definition that did not require an existential quantification, by passing the index M as parameter instead.><android.view.View__Tip: Use idiomatic definitions of properties that help automatic provers></android.view.View__Tip: Use idiomatic definitions of properties that help automatic provers><android.view.View__With these definitions, the loop invariant of the external loop can be expressed very easily, based on the properties of that loop described in the article:></android.view.View__With these definitions, the loop invariant of the external loop can be expressed very easily, based on the properties of that loop described in the article:><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));><android.view.View__It gets a bit trickier for the internal loop, as the explanations in the article in terms of values of K before and after I cannot be directly translated into loop invariants. Plus the article talks of going from index I to index I+1 while the code goes from index I-1 and index I (when expressing the loop invariant). That’s where I tried out various loop invariants in my head, with the support of pen-and-paper to understand how the algorithm really worked. And it went 💡 the array stayed sorted at every iteration of the internal loop for all indexes lower than I!></android.view.View__It gets a bit trickier for the internal loop, as the explanations in the article in terms of values of K before and after I cannot be directly translated into loop invariants. Plus the article talks of going from index I to index I+1 while the code goes from index I-1 and index I (when expressing the loop invariant). That’s where I tried out various loop invariants in my head, with the support of pen-and-paper to understand how the algorithm really worked. And it went 💡 the array stayed sorted at every iteration of the internal loop for all indexes lower than I!><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));><android.view.View__And during the internal loop, the maximum value over the whole array was either located at index I-1 (at the beginning of the iteration) or at index I (after getting to iteration J = I-1):></android.view.View__And during the internal loop, the maximum value over the whole array was either located at index I-1 (at the beginning of the iteration) or at index I (after getting to iteration J = I-1):><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
   (declare
       M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
    begin
       Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
   (declare
       M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
    begin
       Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last));><android.view.View__Tip: Use pen-and-paper to really understand the code that you want to prove></android.view.View__Tip: Use pen-and-paper to really understand the code that you want to prove><android.view.View__It’s all too easy to “understand” that something works by going through the steps of an explanation/demonstration (like in the article), without being able to really understand why it works. Proof requires us to understand why it works.></android.view.View__It’s all too easy to “understand” that something works by going through the steps of an explanation/demonstration (like in the article), without being able to really understand why it works. Proof requires us to understand why it works.><android.view.View__As GNATprove could not prove the loop invariant of the inner loop, even at level 4 (all provers get called at that level, with a substantial timeout of 60 seconds per check), I tried running the program through its test with assertions enabled, and… the loop invariant failed at runtime! No wonder GNATprove could not prove it.></android.view.View__As GNATprove could not prove the loop invariant of the inner loop, even at level 4 (all provers get called at that level, with a substantial timeout of 60 seconds per check), I tried running the program through its test with assertions enabled, and… the loop invariant failed at runtime! No wonder GNATprove could not prove it.><android.view.View__Tip: Execute assertions during tests to help debug them></android.view.View__Tip: Execute assertions during tests to help debug them><android.view.View__Just looking at the failing loop invariant, I realized that it could not be true during the first iteration of the loop, where we have not yet identified the maximum value of the array.   (if I = A'First then
     Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
   else
      (declare
          M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
       begin
          Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
  (if I = A'First then
     Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
   else
      (declare
          M : constant I_Type := (if J < I then I-1 else I);
       begin
          Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));><android.view.View__But the test was still failing at runtime! That was a case of off-by-one error, the test “J < I” in the definition of constant M should be “J < I-1”. With that, the test was running without error.></android.view.View__But the test was still failing at runtime! I read again the explanations in the article, which confirmed that it was true. Yet it was not proved. So I looked at the code, to see how the loop invariant at iteration J can be deduced from the loop invariant at iteration J-1 and the execution of the current iteration. And it was not provable! Because we were missing the information that, up to value J=I-1, the value at index I is greater than all values seen so far:></android.view.View__I reran GNATprove on the code.
