So I looked at the code, to see how the loop invariant at iteration J can be deduced from the loop invariant at iteration J-1 and the execution of the current iteration. And it was not provable! Because we were missing the information that, up to value J=I-1, the value at index I is greater than all values seen so far:><android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant
   (if J < I then
      (for all K in A'First .. J => A(K) <= A(I)));></android.view.View__pragma Loop_Invariant

></android.view.View__
></android.view.View__><android.view.View__pragma Ada_2022;

procedure Stupid_Sort with SPARK_Mode => On
is
   type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. Integer'Last;
   subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
   type A_Type is array (I_Type range <>) of Natural;

   function Sorted (A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
      (for all I in From .. To =>
         (for all J in I .. To =>
            A(I) <= A(J)))
   with
     Pre => From in A'Range
       and then To <= A'Last;

   function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
     (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
   with
     Pre => M in From .. To
       and then From in A'Range
       and then To in A'Range;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   with
     Post => (if A'Length > 0 then Sorted (A, A'First, A'Last))
   is
   begin
      for I in A'range loop
         for J in A'range loop
            if A(I) < A(J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A(I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
            end if;

            pragma Loop_Invariant (if J < I then A(J) <= A(I));
            pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I-1));
            pragma Loop_Invariant
              (if I = A'First then
                Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
              else
                (declare
                   M : constant I_Type := (if J < I-1 then I-1 else I);
                 begin
                   Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));
         end loop;

         pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
         pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type (1 .. 1000);
begin
   for I in A'Range loop
     A (I) := Integer (A'Last - I + 1);
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;></android.view.View__pragma Ada_2022;

procedure Stupid_Sort with SPARK_Mode => On
is
   type I_Type_Base is new Integer range 0 .. Integer'Last;
   subtype I_Type is I_Type_Base range 1 .. I_Type_Base'Last;
   type A_Type is array (I_Type range <>) of Natural;

   function Sorted (A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
      (for all I in From .. To =>
         (for all J in I .. To =>
            A(I) <= A(J)))
   with
     Pre => From in A'Range
       and then To <= A'Last;

   function Is_Max (M : I_Type; A : A_Type; From, To : I_Type_Base) return Boolean is
     (for all I in From .. To => A (I) <= A (M))
   with
     Pre => M in From .. To
       and then From in A'Range
       and then To in A'Range;

   procedure Sort (A : in out A_Type)
   with
     Post => (if A'Length > 0 then Sorted (A, A'First, A'Last))
   is
   begin
      for I in A'range loop
         for J in A'range loop
            if A(I) < A(J) then
               declare
                  Tmp : constant Natural := A(I);
               begin
                  A (I) := A (J);
                  A (J) := Tmp;
               end;
            end if;

            pragma Loop_Invariant (if J < I then A(J) <= A(I));
            pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I-1));
            pragma Loop_Invariant
              (if I = A'First then
                Is_Max (I, A, A'First, J)
              else
                (declare
                   M : constant I_Type := (if J < I-1 then I-1 else I);
                 begin
                   Is_Max (M, A, A'First, A'Last)));
         end loop;

         pragma Loop_Invariant (Sorted (A, A'First, I));
         pragma Loop_Invariant (Is_Max (I, A, A'First, A'Last));
      end loop;
   end Sort;

   A : A_Type (1 .. 1000);
begin
   for I in A'Range loop
     A (I) := Integer (A'Last - I + 1);
   end loop;

   Sort (A);
end Stupid_Sort;><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Posted in ></android.view.View__Posted in ><android.view.View__#SPARK></android.view.View__#SPARK><android.view.View__    ></android.view.View__    ><android.view.View__#Proof></android.view.View__#Proof><android.view.View__    ></android.view.View__    ><android.view.View__#Algorithms></android.view.View__#Algorithms><android.view.View__   ></android.view.View__   ></android.view.View__><android.view.View__About ><android.view.View__About ></android.view.View__About ><android.view.View__Yannick Moy></android.view.View__Yannick Moy></android.view.View__About ><android.widget.Image__Yannick Moy></android.widget.Image__Yannick Moy><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Yannick Moy is Static Analysis Lead at AdaCore. ', ix=''}, comp{id=214, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Toni Adcock - July 3, 2022 12:57 pm', ix=''}, comp{id=215, n='android.view.View', t='', d='There are many stories like this…people are good and want to help. It’s nice to be reminded in times like these.', ix=''}, comp{id=216, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=217, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Reply', ix=''}, comp{id=218, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm Sean, your gift of encouragement is an essential service to your fellow humans! Thank you for highlighting this example of the folks of Mendon, part of the backbone of our country.
I was deeply formed by growing up in a Great Small Town of America. In our metropolis of 450 people, a tiny farming community in East central Illinois, our family home on the edge of town was nestled in between corn fields on two sides and a railroad on the third, with the front of the house facing the street.
My earliest memories include the Christmas season that our house caught on fire while many people–including our family of eight–were visiting Santa Claus up at the firehouse as the call came in. Nobody had to ask for volunteers to help put out the flames or tend to us children while our parents focused on salvaging belongings, because the whole town immediately moved en masse to our front yard to help out in any way they could.
We were fed and clothed and housed by our fellow townspeople until Mom found a place for us to stay while Dad and friends built our new home over the ashes of our old one.
I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me. Missouri. Population 171. There’s really nothing here. The tiny town is located off Route 11, just south of Yellow Creek. You’re three hours west of Saint Louis, two hours east of Kansas City.></android.view.View__Mendon, Missouri. Population 171. There’s really nothing here. The tiny town is located off Route 11, just south of Yellow Creek. You’re three hours west of Saint Louis, two hours east of Kansas City.><android.view.View__It’s quiet. No attractions. No major landmarks. Nobody famous ever lived here unless you count Vern Kennedy, right-hander for the White Sox, circa 1934.></android.view.View__It’s quiet. No attractions. No major landmarks. Nobody famous ever lived here unless you count Vern Kennedy, right-hander for the White Sox, circa 1934.><android.view.View__If you’re looking for entertainment in Mendon, your main option is Busch Light. But you’ll have to drive all the way to Brunswick to find a liquor store.></android.view.View__If you’re looking for entertainment in Mendon, your main option is Busch Light. But you’ll have to drive all the way to Brunswick to find a liquor store.><android.view.View__“We are just country folk,” said Mendon native Carol Ann Wamsley, “and that’s what makes us a special place.”></android.view.View__“We are just country folk,” said Mendon native Carol Ann Wamsley, “and that’s what makes us a special place.”><android.view.View__At its heart, Mendon is a railroad town. The first iron tracks were laid in 1887. Within a decade, a town sprang up. You had a few dozen storefronts, a school, a newspaper, and a couple churches with steeply conflicting views on eternal damnation. Most of that is gone now.></android.view.View__At its heart, Mendon is a railroad town. The first iron tracks were laid in 1887. Within a decade, a town sprang up. You had a few dozen storefronts, a school, a newspaper, and a couple churches with steeply conflicting views on eternal damnation. Most of that is gone now.><android.view.View__Today, the Atchison Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad line still passes the northwest side of the community, only now it’s the Southern Transcon Railroad.></android.view.View__Today, the Atchison Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad line still passes the northwest side of the community, only now it’s the Southern Transcon Railroad.><android.view.View__The Amtrak Southwest Chief runs through town regularly. On summer afternoons you can see the Amtrak locomotive in the distance, racing across the prairie like a polished chromium bullet. But the train never stops here. It just keeps moving.></android.view.View__The Amtrak Southwest Chief runs through town regularly. On summer afternoons you can see the Amtrak locomotive in the distance, racing across the prairie like a polished chromium bullet. But the train never stops here. It just keeps moving.><android.view.View__Until last week.></android.view.View__Until last week.><android.view.View__It was a Monday that will live in infamy. The Southwest Chief made an unexpected stop near Mendon, of all places.></android.view.View__It was a Monday that will live in infamy. The Southwest Chief made an unexpected stop near Mendon, of all places.><android.view.View__The Chief was traveling 87 mph, bound for Chicago. There were more people aboard than there are living within Mendon’s city limits.></android.view.View__The Chief was traveling 87 mph, bound for Chicago. There were more people aboard than there are living within Mendon’s city limits.><android.view.View__Up ahead a dump truck was on the tracks. The truck was obstructing the crossing of County Road 113. This was not a small truck. This was a vehicle about the size of a Sonic Drive-In.></android.view.View__Up ahead a dump truck was on the tracks. The truck was obstructing the crossing of County Road 113. This was not a small truck. This was a vehicle about the size of a Sonic Drive-In.><android.view.View__The train never slowed.></android.view.View__The train never slowed.><android.view.View__The sound of the collision could be heard from as far away as Westville. It was the noise of two General Electric diesel locomotives and seven Superliner cars plowing into a mass of Dearborn steel. The train was derailed.></android.view.View__The sound of the collision could be heard from as far away as Westville. It was the noise of two General Electric diesel locomotives and seven Superliner cars plowing into a mass of Dearborn steel. The train was derailed.><android.view.View__Ron Goulet was riding coach.></android.view.View__Ron Goulet was riding coach.><android.view.View__“…I was airborne. Everything was tumbling. People on top of people. The train rolled on its right side—the entire train, except for the front locomotive.”></android.view.View__“…I was airborne. Everything was tumbling. People on top of people. The train rolled on its right side—the entire train, except for the front locomotive.”><android.view.View__Carry-on bags went everywhere. Elbows collided with craniums. Shoes crashed into jaws. Children clashed against the ceiling.></android.view.View__Carry-on bags went everywhere. Elbows collided with craniums. Shoes crashed into jaws. Children clashed against the ceiling.><android.view.View__“When I climbed up and out of the train…” said Ron, “I was stunned that the entire thing was lying on its side. Not in a jumbled mass, but all laid over on the side.”></android.view.View__“When I climbed up and out of the train…” said Ron, “I was stunned that the entire thing was lying on its side. Not in a jumbled mass, but all laid over on the side.”><android.view.View__The story made national headlines, of course. Reporters from national newspapers visited. They photographed, videoed and wrote. Cable news anchors wore frowny faces and mentioned the wreck, just before cutting to commercials urging elderly viewers to reverse mortgage their livers.></android.view.View__The story made national headlines, of course. Reporters from national newspapers visited. They photographed, videoed and wrote. Cable news anchors wore frowny faces and mentioned the wreck, just before cutting to commercials urging elderly viewers to reverse mortgage their livers.><android.view.View__But somehow, the bigger story about what happened in Mendon was lost. Somehow, you didn’t hear about Mendon’s magnificent people.></android.view.View__But somehow, the bigger story about what happened in Mendon was lost. Somehow, you didn’t hear about Mendon’s magnificent people.><android.view.View__Sure, you heard about the wreck itself; the 150 injured, and the four fatalities. But you didn’t hear about how the residents of Mendon—nearly every single resident—rushed to the scene of the accident.></android.view.View__Sure, you heard about the wreck itself; the 150 injured, and the four fatalities. But you didn’t hear about how the residents of Mendon—nearly every single resident—rushed to the scene of the accident.><android.view.View__Throngs of ordinary townspeople arrived before first responders even knew about the crash. There were volunteers crawling out of the wallpaper.></android.view.View__Throngs of ordinary townspeople arrived before first responders even knew about the crash. There were volunteers crawling out of the wallpaper.><android.view.View__“It was a wonderful problem to have,” said school district superintendent, Eric Hoyt, “but we probably had too many volunteers show up.”></android.view.View__“It was a wonderful problem to have,” said school district superintendent, Eric Hoyt, “but we probably had too many volunteers show up.”><android.view.View__People came from all over Chariton County, riding beat-up Silverados, ATVs, or arriving on foot. They came from Sumner, Marceline, Cunningham, Brookfield and Indian Grove.></android.view.View__People came from all over Chariton County, riding beat-up Silverados, ATVs, or arriving on foot. They came from Sumner, Marceline, Cunningham, Brookfield and Indian Grove.><android.view.View__Two Boy Scout troops dutifully helped injured victims from the wreckage. Local high-schoolers were fashioning bandages out of bandannas. Old women recited the Lord’s Prayer alongside strangers in blood-stained clothes.></android.view.View__Two Boy Scout troops dutifully helped injured victims from the wreckage. Local high-schoolers were fashioning bandages out of bandannas. Old women recited the Lord’s Prayer alongside strangers in blood-stained clothes.><android.view.View__There were farmers, off-duty nurses, truck drivers, soccer moms, Little League coaches and grade-schoolers. They were doling out food, first aid, bottled water and, most importantly, phone chargers.></android.view.View__There were farmers, off-duty nurses, truck drivers, soccer moms, Little League coaches and grade-schoolers. They were doling out food, first aid, bottled water and, most importantly, phone chargers.><android.view.View__Victims were taken to local homes, fed, bathed and bandaged. Weeping passengers were embraced by rural preachers. Passengers using wheelchairs were lifted from the rubble by young men in ropers and camouflage caps.></android.view.View__Victims were taken to local homes, fed, bathed and bandaged. Weeping passengers were embraced by rural preachers. Passengers using wheelchairs were lifted from the rubble by young men in ropers and camouflage caps.><android.view.View__Local schoolbus drivers transported the wounded to hospitals. Northwestern High School staff members triaged victims in the gymnasium and fed people in the cafeteria.></android.view.View__Local schoolbus drivers transported the wounded to hospitals. Northwestern High School staff members triaged victims in the gymnasium and fed people in the cafeteria.><android.view.View__One resident said that Mendon didn’t feel like a 171-person town anymore. “It was like 671 people came together.”></android.view.View__One resident said that Mendon didn’t feel like a 171-person town anymore. “It was like 671 people came together.”><android.view.View__And the most unusual thing about all this is: None of this is unusual. At least not within the national tapestry that is The Great American Small Town.></android.view.View__And the most unusual thing about all this is: None of this is unusual. At least not within the national tapestry that is The Great American Small Town.><android.view.View__Although we rarely hear about such acts of compassion and lovingkindness within our society, believe me, they happen. Maybe part of our problem as Americans is we don’t have something big to bring us together. It’s nice to be reminded in times like these. ><android.view.View__Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm Sean, your gift of encouragement is an essential service to your fellow humans! Thank you for highlighting this example of the folks of Mendon, part of the backbone of our country.
I was deeply formed by growing up in a Great Small Town of America. In our metropolis of 450 people, a tiny farming community in East central Illinois, our family home on the edge of town was nestled in between corn fields on two sides and a railroad on the third, with the front of the house facing the street.
My earliest memories include the Christmas season that our house caught on fire while many people–including our family of eight–were visiting Santa Claus up at the firehouse as the call came in. Nobody had to ask for volunteers to help put out the flames or tend to us children while our parents focused on salvaging belongings, because the whole town immediately moved en masse to our front yard to help out in any way they could.
We were fed and clothed and housed by our fellow townspeople until Mom found a place for us to stay while Dad and friends built our new home over the ashes of our old one.
I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me. ><android.view.View__Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm></android.view.View__Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Sean, your gift of encouragement is an essential service to your fellow humans! ><android.view.View__I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me.></android.view.View__I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Reply></android.view.View__Reply></android.view.View__></android.view.View__Lyn Cogswell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm Sean, your gift of encouragement is an essential service to your fellow humans! Thank you for highlighting this example of the folks of Mendon, part of the backbone of our country.
I was deeply formed by growing up in a Great Small Town of America. In our metropolis of 450 people, a tiny farming community in East central Illinois, our family home on the edge of town was nestled in between corn fields on two sides and a railroad on the third, with the front of the house facing the street.
My earliest memories include the Christmas season that our house caught on fire while many people–including our family of eight–were visiting Santa Claus up at the firehouse as the call came in. Nobody had to ask for volunteers to help put out the flames or tend to us children while our parents focused on salvaging belongings, because the whole town immediately moved en masse to our front yard to help out in any way they could.
We were fed and clothed and housed by our fellow townspeople until Mom found a place for us to stay while Dad and friends built our new home over the ashes of our old one.
I believe one of the reasons I ended up finding my calling in hospital chaplaincy thousands of miles and many decades away from our rural hometown is tied to the continual, compassionate examples set by the community that helped raise me. ><android.view.View__David Britnell - July 3, 2022 1:01 pm I think small town USA people have more of a sense of community in general. I can ask almost anyone in my little town of Hardy, AR for help and I would have no trouble getting it. Ever been to Clio, South Carolina? Pronounced Clyoh. Small town on a short-cut to Myrtle Beach from Charlotte. Name came from ‘Stop Number Ten on the old Coast Line — CL ten — CLIO. If you are ever there, check out an old plantation house called ‘Harleanton’, bought and restored by Dr. Harley Davidson. Harley’s widow or maybe his son probably still live there. ><android.view.View__Patricia Gibson - July 3, 2022 4:12 pm Thank you, Sean! So it probably isn’t worth dealing with the portability issues of working with wide vector registers. (Especially since I could not find a quick way to load an arbitrary number of bytes into a vector register with AVX2 nor with NEON.)', ix=''}, comp{id=60, n='android.view.View', t='', d='bytewise parallel tolower()', ix=''}, comp{id=61, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=62, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Hacker’s Delight', ix=''}, comp{id=63, n='android.view.View', t='', d=' has a lot of discussion of this kind of SWAR string processing code, but it does not directly tackle ', ix=''}, comp{id=64, n='android.view.View', t='', d='tolower()', ix=''}, comp{id=65, n='android.view.View', t='', d='. ', ix=''}, comp{id=68, n='android.view.View', t='', d='For readability, it’s helpful to be able to replicate a single-byte value to all 8 bytes in a word. To do so we can multiply by a constant that has a 1 in each byte. The compiler’s constant propagation and instruction selection will make this efficient for us.', ix=''}, comp{id=69, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    uint64_t all_bytes = 0x0101010101010101;
', ix=''}, comp{id=70, n='android.view.View', t='', d='We are going to steal the 0x80 bit in each byte to use as a flag for various purposes.', ix=''}, comp{id=71, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    uint64_t heptets = octets & (0x7F * all_bytes);
', ix=''}, comp{id=72, n='android.view.View', t='', d='The main trick we’ll use from Hank Warren is how to find out which bytes are greater than a particular constant, such as 'Z'. If we add 0x7Fto any of our bytes, carries will propagate and the result will overflow into our 0x80 flag bit only if the byte is greater than zero. And because we cleared the flag bits, they act as fire breaks stopping the carries from lower bytes messing up the calculations for higher bytes.', ix=''}, comp{id=73, n='android.view.View', t='', d='To compare with a value other than zero, we can subtract it from 0x7F:', ix=''}, comp{id=74, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    uint64_t is_gt_Z = heptets + (0x7F - 'Z') * all_bytes;
', ix=''}, comp{id=75, n='android.view.View', t='', d='To do a greater-than-or-equal comparison, we just need to add 1:', ix=''}, comp{id=76, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    uint64_t is_ge_A = heptets + (0x80 - 'A') * all_bytes;
', ix=''}, comp{id=77, n='android.view.View', t='', d='The flags we just calculated are only valid if the corresponding octet is in the ASCII range of 0 to 127. So we need a clear flag for each byte that is 128 or greater.', ix=''}, comp{id=78, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    uint64_t is_ascii = ~octets;
', ix=''}, comp{id=79, n='android.view.View', t='', d='We are now ready to identify which bytes contain upper case ASCII letters:', ix=''}, comp{id=80, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    uint64_t is_upper = is_ascii & (is_ge_A ^ is_gt_Z);
', ix=''}, comp{id=81, n='android.view.View', t='', d='The difference between corresponding upper case and lower case letters in ASCII is 32, aka 0x20. So to get our conversion value, we need to move our 0x80 flag bits to 0x20, and clear out the junk that our calculations left behind in the other bits:', ix=''}, comp{id=82, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    uint64_t to_lower = (is_upper >> 2) & (0x20 * all_bytes);
', ix=''}, comp{id=83, n='android.view.View', t='', d='All that’s left is to add our flag bits to the original word, so that each byte that was an ASCII upper case letter has 32 added to change it to lower case.', ix=''}, comp{id=84, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    return (octets | to_lower);
}
', ix=''}, comp{id=85, n='android.view.View', t='', d='That should compile down to about 9 instructions, which is not much more than one instruction per byte. And these are the fastest kinds of instructions :-)', ix=''}, comp{id=86, n='android.view.View', t='', d='edited to add', ix=''}, comp{id=87, n='android.view.View', t='', d='We can reduce the critical path from 7 to 6 instructions with a slight adjustment: changeis_ascii and the return value as follows, and delete to_lower.', ix=''}, comp{id=88, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    uint64_t is_ascii = ~octets & (0x80 * all_bytes);
    return (octets | is_upper >> 2);
', ix=''}, comp{id=89, n='android.view.View', t='', d='performance numbers', ix=''}, comp{id=90, n='android.view.View', t='', d='I ran some basic benchmarks on a million random bytes to see how this code compares to one-byte-at-a-time tolower():', ix=''}, comp{id=91, n='android.view.View', t='', d='    0.098 ms memmove() copy
    0.399 ms tolower8() copy
    1.817 ms tolower() copy
    0.280 ms tolower8() compare
    2.090 ms tolower() compare
', ix=''}, comp{id=92, n='android.view.View', t='', d='The copy lines are for making a new lower-case version of the string. The compare lines are for testing two strings for case-insensitive equality.', ix=''}, comp{id=93, n='android.view.View', t='', d='My tolower8() function is at its best when it has a lot to chew on; it is not so good for really short strings. The crossover point, when comparing two strings, is about 4 characters - conveniently, the same length as .com. (There is a trick for 4-character strings: load them both into the same register so they can both be converted to lower case at the same time.)', ix=''}, comp{id=94, n='android.view.View', t='', d='So So it probably isn’t worth dealing with the portability issues of working with wide vector registers. (Especially since I could not find a quick way to load an arbitrary number of bytes into a vector register with AVX2 nor with NEON.)></android.view.View__Code often needs to work with DNS names one label at a time (the labels are the dot-separated parts), and labels are frequently less than 8 bytes long, and therefore fit inside a 64-bit register. (Especially since I could not find a quick way to load an arbitrary number of bytes into a vector register with AVX2 nor with NEON.)><android.view.View__bytewise parallel tolower()></android.view.View__bytewise parallel tolower()><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Hacker’s Delight></android.view.View__Hacker’s Delight><android.view.View__ has a lot of discussion of this kind of SWAR string processing code, but it does not directly tackle ></android.view.View__ has a lot of discussion of this kind of SWAR string processing code, but it does not directly tackle ><android.view.View__tolower()></android.view.View__tolower()><android.view.View__. So, here’s how I adapted Hank Warren’s examples for my purposes.></android.view.View__. So, here’s how I adapted Hank Warren’s examples for my purposes.></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Our function is going to work on 8 ASCII bytes packed into a uint64_t.></android.view.View__Our function is going to work on 8 ASCII bytes packed into a uint64_t.><android.view.View__uint64_t tolower8(uint64_t octets) {
></android.view.View__uint64_t tolower8(uint64_t octets) {
><android.view.View__For readability, it’s helpful to be able to replicate a single-byte value to all 8 bytes in a word. To do so we can multiply by a constant that has a 1 in each byte. The compiler’s constant propagation and instruction selection will make this efficient for us.></android.view.View__For readability, it’s helpful to be able to replicate a single-byte value to all 8 bytes in a word. To do so we can multiply by a constant that has a 1 in each byte. The compiler’s constant propagation and instruction selection will make this efficient for us.><android.view.View__    uint64_t all_bytes = 0x0101010101010101;
></android.view.View__    uint64_t all_bytes = 0x0101010101010101;
><android.view.View__We are going to steal the 0x80 bit in each byte to use as a flag for various purposes.></android.view.View__We are going to steal the 0x80 bit in each byte to use as a flag for various purposes.><android.view.View__    uint64_t heptets = octets & (0x7F * all_bytes);
></android.view.View__    uint64_t heptets = octets & (0x7F * all_bytes);
><android.view.View__The main trick we’ll use from Hank Warren is how to find out which bytes are greater than a particular constant, such as 'Z'. If we add 0x7Fto any of our bytes, carries will propagate and the result will overflow into our 0x80 flag bit only if the byte is greater than zero. And because we cleared the flag bits, they act as fire breaks stopping the carries from lower bytes messing up the calculations for higher bytes.></android.view.View__The main trick we’ll use from Hank Warren is how to find out which bytes are greater than a particular constant, such as 'Z'. If we add 0x7Fto any of our bytes, carries will propagate and the result will overflow into our 0x80 flag bit only if the byte is greater than zero. And because we cleared the flag bits, they act as fire breaks stopping the carries from lower bytes messing up the calculations for higher bytes.><android.view.View__To compare with a value other than zero, we can subtract it from 0x7F:></android.view.View__To compare with a value other than zero, we can subtract it from 0x7F:><android.view.View__    uint64_t is_gt_Z = heptets + (0x7F - 'Z') * all_bytes;
></android.view.View__    uint64_t is_gt_Z = heptets + (0x7F - 'Z') * all_bytes;
><android.view.View__To do a greater-than-or-equal comparison, we just need to add 1:></android.view.View__To do a greater-than-or-equal comparison, we just need to add 1:><android.view.View__    uint64_t is_ge_A = heptets + (0x80 - 'A') * all_bytes;
></android.view.View__    uint64_t is_ge_A = heptets + (0x80 - 'A') * all_bytes;
><android.view.View__The flags we just calculated are only valid if the corresponding octet is in the ASCII range of 0 to 127. So we need a clear flag for each byte that is 128 or greater.></android.view.View__The flags we just calculated are only valid if the corresponding octet is in the ASCII range of 0 to 127. So we need a clear flag for each byte that is 128 or greater.><android.view.View__    uint64_t is_ascii = ~octets;
></android.view.View__    uint64_t is_ascii = ~octets;
><android.view.View__We are now ready to identify which bytes contain upper case ASCII letters:></android.view.View__We are now ready to identify which bytes contain upper case ASCII letters:><android.view.View__    uint64_t is_upper = is_ascii & (is_ge_A ^ is_gt_Z);
></android.view.View__    uint64_t is_upper = is_ascii & (is_ge_A ^ is_gt_Z);
><android.view.View__The difference between corresponding upper case and lower case letters in ASCII is 32, aka 0x20. So to get our conversion value, we need to move our 0x80 flag bits to 0x20, and clear out the junk that our calculations left behind in the other bits:></android.view.View__The difference between corresponding upper case and lower case letters in ASCII is 32, aka 0x20. So to get our conversion value, we need to move our 0x80 flag bits to 0x20, and clear out the junk that our calculations left behind in the other bits:><android.view.View__    uint64_t to_lower = (is_upper >> 2) & (0x20 * all_bytes);
></android.view.View__    uint64_t to_lower = (is_upper >> 2) & (0x20 * all_bytes);
><android.view.View__All that’s left is to add our flag bits to the original word, so that each byte that was an ASCII upper case letter has 32 added to change it to lower case.></android.view.View__All that’s left is to add our flag bits to the original word, so that each byte that was an ASCII upper case letter has 32 added to change it to lower case.><android.view.View__    return (octets | to_lower);
}
></android.view.View__    return (octets | to_lower);
}
><android.view.View__That should compile down to about 9 instructions, which is not much more than one instruction per byte. And these are the fastest kinds of instructions :-)></android.view.View__That should compile down to about 9 instructions, which is not much more than one instruction per byte. And these are the fastest kinds of instructions :-)><android.view.View__edited to add></android.view.View__edited to add><android.view.View__We can reduce the critical path from 7 to 6 instructions with a slight adjustment: changeis_ascii and the return value as follows, and delete to_lower.></android.view.View__We can reduce the critical path from 7 to 6 instructions with a slight adjustment: changeis_ascii and the return value as follows, and delete to_lower.><android.view.View__    uint64_t is_ascii = ~octets & (0x80 * all_bytes);
    return (octets | is_upper >> 2);
></android.view.View__    uint64_t is_ascii = ~octets & (0x80 * all_bytes);
    return (octets | is_upper >> 2);
><android.view.View__performance numbers></android.view.View__performance numbers><android.view.View__I ran some basic benchmarks on a million random bytes to see how this code compares to one-byte-at-a-time tolower():></android.view.View__I ran some basic benchmarks on a million random bytes to see how this code compares to one-byte-at-a-time tolower():><android.view.View__    0.098 ms memmove() copy
    0.399 ms tolower8() copy
    1.817 ms tolower() copy
    0.280 ms tolower8() compare
    2.090 ms tolower() compare
></android.view.View__    0.098 ms memmove() copy
    0.399 ms tolower8() copy
    1.817 ms tolower() copy
    0.280 ms tolower8() compare
    2.090 ms tolower() compare
><android.view.View__The copy lines are for making a new lower-case version of the string. The compare lines are for testing two strings for case-insensitive equality.></android.view.View__The copy lines are for making a new lower-case version of the string. The compare lines are for testing two strings for case-insensitive equality.><android.view.View__My tolower8() function is at its best when it has a lot to chew on; it is not so good for really short strings. The crossover point, when comparing two strings, is about 4 characters - conveniently, the same length as .com. (There is a trick for 4-character strings: load them both into the same register so they can both be converted to lower case at the same time.)></android.view.View__My tolower8() function is at its best when it has a lot to chew on; it is not so good for really short strings. The crossover point, when comparing two strings, is about 4 characters - conveniently, the same length as .com. (There is a trick for 4-character strings: load them both into the same register so they can both be converted to lower case at the same time.)><android.view.View__So now you know how to convert strings to lower case at gigabytes per second in a single thread.></android.view.View__So now you know how to convert strings to lower case at gigabytes per second in a single thread.><android.view.View__⇐ 2022-06-22 ⇐ Compacting a qp-trie ⇐></android.view.View__⇐ 2022-06-22 ⇐ Compacting a qp-trie ⇐><android.view.View__⇒ ☆ ⇒ ☆ ⇒></android.view.View__⇒ ☆ ⇒ ☆ ⇒><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Tony Finch></android.view.View__Tony Finch><android.view.View__<></android.view.View__<><android.view.View__dot@dotat.at></android.view.View__dot@dotat.at><android.view.View__>></android.view.View__>></android.view.View__></android.webkit.WebView__tolower() in bulk at speed – Tony Finch></android.webkit.WebView__></android.view.ViewGroup_com.hexforhn.hex:webview_layout_></android.support.v4.view.ViewPager_com.hexforhn.hex:pager_></android.widget.LinearLayout__></android.widget.FrameLayout_android:content_></android.widget.LinearLayout_com.hexforhn.hex:action_bar_root_></android.widget.FrameLayout__></android.widget.LinearLayout__><android.view.View_android:statusBarBackground_></android.view.View_android:statusBarBackground_><android.view.View_android:navigationBarBackground_></android.view.View_android:navigationBarBackground_></android.widget.FrameLayout__></_NO_ID_null> - com.hexforhn.hex.Bottom_Up.Expected..1.com.hexforhn.hex_0.1.0_1.png

Various stories relate how at some point in the past either students or fellows of the University attempted to take the bridge apart and put it back together, but were unable to work out how to hold the structure together, and were obliged to resort to adding nuts and bolts. In reality, bolts or the equivalent are an inherent part of the design. When it was first built, iron spikes were driven into the joints from the outer side, where they could not be seen from the inside of the parapets, explaining why bolts were thought to be an addition to the original. Newton could not have been directly involved since he died in 1727, twenty-two years before the bridge was constructed.', ix=''}, comp{id=169, n='android.view.View', t='', d='[7]', ix=''}, comp{id=170, n='android.view.View', t='', d='See also ', ix=''}, comp{id=171, n='android.view.View', t='', d='See also', ix=''}, comp{id=172, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Edit', ix=''}, comp{id=173, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=174, n='android.widget.ListView', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=175, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=176, n='android.view.View', t='', d='•', ix=''}, comp{id=177, n='android.view.View', t='', d='List of bridges in Cambridge', ix=''}, comp{id=178, n='android.view.View', t='', d=', a larger bridge on the same principle, also designed by William Etheridge.', ix=''}, comp{id=179, n='android.view.View', t='', d='•', ix=''}, comp{id=180, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Old Walton Bridge', ix=''}, comp{id=181, n='android.view.View', t='', d=', a larger bridge on the same principle, also designed by William Etheridge.', ix=''}, comp{id=182, n='android.view.View', t='', d='References ', ix=''}, comp{id=183, n='android.view.View', t='', d='References', ix=''}, comp{id=184, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Edit', ix=''}, comp{id=185, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=186, n='android.view.View', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=187, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Wikimedia Commons has media related to', ix=''}, comp{id=188, n='android.view.View', t='', d='Mathematical Bridge', ix=''}, comp{id=189, n='android.view.View', t='', d='.', ix=''}, comp{id=190, n='android.widget.ListView', t='', d='', ix=''}, comp{id=191, n='android.view.View', t='', d='^   . . . almost entirely subject to tension with very little bending stress, or to put it another way, the tangent and radial elements elegantly express the forces involved in arched construction.></android.view.View__ Analysis of the design shows that the tangent members are almost entirely under compression, while the radial timbers are almost entirely subject to tension with very little bending stress, or to put it another way, the tangent and radial elements elegantly express the forces involved in arched construction.></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__Myths ><android.view.View__Myths></android.view.View__Myths><android.view.View__Edit></android.view.View__Edit></android.view.View__Myths ><android.view.View__><android.view.View__File:MathematicalBridge1865></android.view.View__File:MathematicalBridge1865><android.view.View__The Mathematical Bridge (approx. 1865) pictured shortly before it was partially rebuilt in 1866.></android.view.View__The Mathematical Bridge (approx. 1865) pictured shortly before it was partially rebuilt in 1866.><android.view.View__><android.view.View__A popular fable is that the bridge was designed and built by Sir ></android.view.View__A popular fable is that the bridge was designed and built by Sir ><android.view.View__Isaac Newton></android.view.View__Isaac Newton><android.view.View__ without the use of nuts or bolts. Various stories relate how at some point in the past either students or fellows of the University attempted to take the bridge apart and put it back together, but were unable to work out how to hold the structure together, and were obliged to resort to adding nuts and bolts. In reality, bolts or the equivalent are an inherent part of the design. When it was first built, iron spikes were driven into the joints from the outer side, where they could not be seen from the inside of the parapets, explaining why bolts were thought to be an addition to the original. Newton could not have been directly involved since he died in 1727, twenty-two years before the bridge was constructed.></android.view.View__ without the use of nuts or bolts. Various stories relate how at some point in the past either students or fellows of the University attempted to take the bridge apart and put it back together, but were unable to work out how to hold the structure together, and were obliged to resort to adding nuts and bolts. In reality, bolts or the equivalent are an inherent part of the design. When it was first built, iron spikes were driven into the joints from the outer side, where they could not be seen from the inside of the parapets, explaining why bolts were thought to be an addition to the original. Newton could not have been directly involved since he died in 1727, twenty-two years before the bridge was constructed.><android.view.View__[7]></android.view.View__[7]></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__See also ><android.view.View__See also></android.view.View__See also><android.view.View__Edit></android.view.View__Edit></android.view.View__See also ><android.view.View__><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__List of bridges in Cambridge></android.view.View__List of bridges in Cambridge></android.view.View__><android.view.View__, a larger bridge on the same principle, also designed by William Etheridge.><android.view.View__•></android.view.View__•><android.view.View__Old Walton Bridge></android.view.View__Old Walton Bridge><android.view.View__, a larger bridge on the same principle, also designed by William Etheridge.></android.view.View__, a larger bridge on the same principle, also designed by William Etheridge.></android.view.View__, a larger bridge on the same principle, also designed by William Etheridge.></android.widget.ListView__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__References ><android.view.View__References></android.view.View__References><android.view.View__Edit></android.view.View__Edit></android.view.View__References ><android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__Wikimedia Commons has media related to></android.view.View__Wikimedia Commons has media related to><android.view.View__Mathematical Bridge></android.view.View__Mathematical Bridge><android.view.View__.></android.view.View__.></android.view.View__><android.widget.ListView__><android.view.View__^   . . . It is trained with images from the [Octodex](1), images shared with [#MyOctocat on Twitter](2), and [photographs of laptops with :octocat: stickers on them]().  ## Installation  ``` git clone https://github.com/jasonetco/octocat-classifier ``` ></android.view.View__# Octocat Classifier :octopus: :cat: :mag:![](https://img.shields.io/badge/build-passing-brightgreen) ![](https://img.shields.io/badge/coverage-90%25-green) ![](https://img.shields.io/badge/dependencies-up%20to%20date-brightgreen)  As the name suggests, Octocat Classifier is used to determine whether a given image contains an Octocat. It is trained with images from the [Octodex](1), images shared with [#MyOctocat on Twitter](2), and [photographs of laptops with :octocat: stickers on them]().  ## Installation  ``` git clone It is trained with images from the [Octodex](1), images shared with [#MyOctocat on Twitter](2), and [photographs of laptops with :octocat: stickers on them]().  ## Installation  ``` git clone https://github.com/jasonetco/octocat-classifier ``` ></android.view.View__# Octocat Classifier :octopus: :cat: :mag:![](https://img.shields.io/badge/build-passing-brightgreen) ![](https://img.shields.io/badge/coverage-90%25-green) ![](https://img.shields.io/badge/dependencies-up%20to%20date-brightgreen)  As the name suggests, Octocat Classifier is used to determine whether a given image contains an Octocat. It is trained with images from the [Octodex](1), images shared with [#MyOctocat on Twitter](2), and [photographs of laptops with :octocat: stickers on them]().  ## Installation  ``` git clone For those wondering, the main difference between these trendy miniaturized computers and "standard" Linux phones can often be just the lack of a cellular modem. In general, the board designs appear to be quite similar between PDAs and phones, and for most applications, a Linux PDA can be cheaper and just as useful as a fully fledged smartphone.></android.view.View__ last month. For those wondering, the main difference between these trendy miniaturized computers and "standard" Linux phones can often be just the lack of a cellular modem. the everyday customer oriented, yet radically open-source nature of this product. While not many technical details are known yet, the PocketReform will focus on a flexible, easily repairable hardware and structure, probably taken at least in part from the full-size Reform laptop. While not many technical details are known yet, the PocketReform will focus on a flexible, easily repairable hardware and structure, probably taken at least in part from the full-size Reform laptop. (more info below)></android.view.View__MNT Pocket Reform is coming! (more info below)><android.view.View__pic.twitter.com/c6g4GG2Nif></android.view.View__pic.twitter.com/c6g4GG2Nif></android.view.View__><android.view.View__><android.view.View__— lukas f. hartmann (@minut_e) ></android.view.View__— lukas f. hartmann (@minut_e) ><android.view.View__June 27, 2022></android.view.View__June 27, 2022></android.view.View__></android.view.View__></android.view.View__><android.view.View__RAM is determined by the base module, and eMMC storage alongside an NVME m.2 SSD slot can be found on the board. Moreover, the PocketReform offers several wireless capabilities, with Wi-Fi 802.11ac and Bluetooth 5.0 in the base model, plus an optional WWAN slot for 5G and 4G modems.></android.view.View__RAM is determined by the base module, and eMMC storage alongside an NVME m.2 SSD slot can be found on the board. Moreover, the PocketReform offers several wireless capabilities, with Wi-Fi 802.11ac and Bluetooth 5.0 in the base model, plus an optional WWAN slot for 5G and 4G modems.><android.view.View__At 20 × 12.6 × 4.5cm, the PocketReform is somewhere in between a handheld and a netbook, and its thickness is wholly justified by the replaceable 18650 Lithium batteries (8000mAh) and overall modularity of the board. These can be charged by one of the two USB-C ports, which supports Power Delivery (PD). A micro-HDMI 4K output and an industrial Ethernet port are also present in the casing.></android.view.View__At 20 × 12.6 × 4.5cm, the PocketReform is somewhere in between a handheld and a netbook, and its thickness is wholly justified by the replaceable 18650 Lithium batteries (8000mAh) and overall modularity of the board. These can be charged by one of the two USB-C ports, which supports Power Delivery (PD). A micro-HDMI 4K output and an industrial Ethernet port are also present in the casing.><android.view.View__Many colours and finishes were showcased in renderings, from a slightly 2000-ish light blue tint, to solid gray, to the amazing wood-and-glass blend of the current prototype, which we would like to see replicated in production. In the end, the case will be either in (cyber-punkish) purple or black anodized aluminium, or in recycled PLA.></android.view.View__Many colours and finishes were showcased in renderings, from a slightly 2000-ish light blue tint, to solid gray, to the amazing wood-and-glass blend of the current prototype, which we would like to see replicated in production. In the end, the case will be either in (cyber-punkish) purple or black anodized aluminium, or in recycled PLA.><android.view.View__The PocketReform supports a range of OS that goes, interestingly, beyond Linux to include OpenBSD and even Plan9 ports.s></android.view.View__The PocketReform supports a range of OS that goes, interestingly, beyond Linux to include OpenBSD and even Plan9 ports.s><android.view.View__In conclusion, this new project looks intriguing to say the least. With funding at least partly ensured, and inheriting expectations from the MNT Reform as a quality product, hopes for the PocketReform are high. You can find more information in the official introduction post below.></android.view.View__In conclusion, this new project looks intriguing to say the least.
